title: The Honeymoon Couple
imageAlt: Traditional trulli houses in Puglia, Italy countryside
travelerType: Newly engaged couple, both 32, working in tech
quote: We want somewhere romantic but not basic. Not Cancun or an all-inclusive. Good food matters more than a beach. We're foodies.
constraints: Must have: Great restaurants nearby, romantic vibe, walkable
Can't do: Long-haul flights (max 8 hours from NYC)
Dealbreaker: "Resort feel" or tourist crowds

eliminated.name: Santorini
eliminated.reason: Peak season crowds, overexposed on Instagram

considered.name: Portugal (Lisbon + Sintra)
considered.reason: Great food, romantic, but they'd been before

considered.name: Amalfi Coast
considered.reason: Stunning but crowded in their window

recommended: Puglia — off-peak pricing, authentic, beaches + food without the crowds

finalBooking.why: Private, romantic, farm-to-table meals included, trulli architecture they'd never seen

outcome: Booked. They sent photos of homemade orecchiette. Called it "the best trip we've ever taken."

title: The Burned-Out Founder
imageAlt: Remote Iceland landscape with dramatic mountains and glacial waters
travelerType: Solo founder, 38, just closed a funding round
quote: I need to disappear for a week. Somewhere I can sleep, read, and not think about work. No emails. No decisions.
constraints: Must have: Privacy, nature, no "scene"
Can't do: Group activities, wellness retreats with schedules
Dealbreaker: Having to plan anything once there

eliminated.name: Typical beach resorts
eliminated.reason: Too many people, too much stimulation

considered.name: Norwegian fjord cabin
considered.reason: Remote but cold in their window

recommended: Remote luxury lodge in Iceland's Westfjords — accessible only by small plane

finalBooking.property: 8-room lodge accessible only by charter flight
finalBooking.why: Total isolation, all meals included, no WiFi by design, hot springs on property
finalBooking.extras: None needed — that was the point

outcome: Booked same day. Texted us after: "I slept 10 hours a night and read 4 books. Thank you."

title: The Anniversary Trip
imageAlt: Old Montreal cobblestone streets with European architecture
travelerType: Couple, late 30s, two kids under 5, haven't traveled alone since 2021
timeline: 6 weeks out, tied to grandparents' availability
quote: We have 4 days without kids. We don't even know what we like anymore. Just... not a theme park and not exhausting.
constraints: Must have: Good food, walkable, feels special but not stuffy
Can't do: Adventure travel, long travel days (wasted time)
Dealbreaker: Anywhere that feels like it's "for young people"

eliminated.name: Caribbean
eliminated.reason: Feels like a "family resort without the family"

eliminated.name: NYC
eliminated.reason: They live 2 hours away, doesn't feel like an escape

recommended: Montreal — feels European, incredible restaurant scene, easy flight, feels "adult"

finalBooking.why: Feels European, incredible restaurant scene, easy flight, felt "adult"

outcome: Booked. They extended by one night (grandparents agreed). Called it "the reset we needed."

title: The Zero Research Executive
imageAlt: London skyline with Tower Bridge at dusk
travelerType: CFO, 52, flies 80+ times a year, zero patience for booking interfaces
timeline: Needs to be in London Monday morning for board meeting
quote: JFK to Heathrow, Sunday night, business class, aisle seat. Arriving before 9am. Go.
constraints: Must have: Business class, aisle, morning arrival
Loyalty: British Airways Executive Club (collect Avios)
No hotel needed. Just the flight.

eliminated.name: Economy options
eliminated.reason: Not an option for this traveler

recommended: BA 178, business class, aisle seat 10C — arrives Monday morning, earns Avios

finalBooking.why: Met all requirements: timing, class, seat preference, loyalty program

outcome: Booked. He texts us every week now. Said: "You're faster than my EA." This person doesn't need recommendations—they need someone to do the clicking.

title: The Last-Minute Celebration
imageAlt: Miami Beach oceanfront with palm trees and Art Deco buildings
travelerType: Investor, 39, deal closed early, wants to celebrate immediately
quote: Miami tomorrow morning, first class if you can get it, I don't care which airline. Need to land by noon. Window seat.
constraints: Must have: First class, window, land by noon
Loyalty: Delta SkyMiles (collect miles)
No hotel needed — staying at friend's place
recommended: Delta 1765 — First class, window seat, arrives before noon, earns SkyMiles

finalBooking.why: Best price, met all requirements, earns Delta miles
finalBooking.extras: SkyMiles number attached, miles credited automatically

outcome: Booked by 9:20pm. Boarding pass in her Apple Wallet before she finished dinner. No apps, no searches — just "this is what I want" → "here are options" → "book #1" → done.

title: The Returning Customer
imageAlt: Iconic yellow tram on Lisbon cobblestone streets
travelerType: Creative director, 36, third trip booked through Otherwhere
quote: Hey, planning another trip. Thinking Barcelona or maybe Lisbon. 4 nights. You know what I like.
constraints: Prefers boutique hotels (no big chains)
Always wants walkable to restaurants
King bed, high floor, quiet room
Doesn't like "scene-y" hotels
United MileagePlus member

eliminated.name: Barcelona
eliminated.reason: Loud in June — not her vibe

eliminated.name: Chain hotels
eliminated.reason: We know she doesn't like them

recommended: Boutique in Príncipe Real — high floor corner room available, matches her pattern

finalBooking.why: We pattern-matched to her taste. High floor, quiet room, walkable to restaurants.
finalBooking.extras: United flight (earns miles), TSA PreCheck info already on file

outcome: Booked in one exchange. She's now on trip #4 planning with us. The value: no re-entering preferences, no explaining "I don't like big hotels" again, no typing passport number.

title: The Status Traveler
travelerType: Management consultant, 41, Marriott Bonvoy Titanium, wants to KEEP earning points
timeline: Planning 2 months ahead for a week off
quote: I want somewhere that's actually good but still Marriott so I get my points and status benefits. Not an airport Marriott. Somewhere I'd actually want to go.
constraints: Must have: Marriott property (to earn points + get Titanium benefits)
Loyalty: Marriott Bonvoy Titanium (earn points, suite upgrades, late checkout)
Dealbreaker: "Might as well be a Courtyard"

considered.name: St. Regis Rome
considered.reason: Luxury tier, points earning, Titanium perks apply

recommended: St. Regis Rome — historic building, butler service, Titanium benefits apply

finalBooking.why: Earns Bonvoy points at luxury rate, Titanium status = suite upgrade likely, doesn't feel like "work travel"
finalBooking.price: $2,800 for 5 nights (paid in cash, earning ~14,000 Bonvoy points)
finalBooking.extras: Bonvoy number already on file, attached to booking automatically

outcome: Got upgraded to a suite on arrival. Said "finally a work trip's worth of points going toward something good." We knew which Marriott brands are actually good—that's the value.

summary.result: St. Regis Rome, upgraded to suite

title: The Surprise Anniversary
imageAlt: Burgundy wine region vineyards at sunset
travelerType: Husband, 45, planning surprise 20th anniversary trip for wife
quote: I want to surprise my wife. She always plans everything. For once, I want to get it right without her help. She loves wine, she's always wanted to go to France, and she doesn't like 'roughing it.'
constraints: Must have: Wine region, France, feels luxurious but not "stuffy rich"
Can't do: Backpacking-style, budget accommodations
Dealbreaker: Messing this up (high stakes)
recommended: Burgundy, based in Beaune — intimate châteaux, world-class wine, feels discovered

finalBooking.why: Intimate, wine tastings on-site, Michelin restaurant, felt "discovered not Googled"
finalBooking.extras: Private vineyard tour ($300), hot air balloon ($450)

outcome: She cried when she found out. He said: "I couldn't have done this alone." We coordinated with the hotel for anniversary surprise (champagne, flowers).

title: The Quick Business Trip
imageAlt: Chicago skyline with Willis Tower and Lake Michigan
travelerType: Sales VP, 47, needs to be in Chicago for a client dinner
budget: Company policy allows up to $800 for domestic flights
quote: ORD tomorrow, any afternoon flight, economy is fine, aisle. Back Thursday red-eye.
constraints: American AAdvantage member
Seat preference: Aisle
TSA PreCheck number on file
Work email for receipts
recommended: AA 1245 — afternoon departure, aisle seat, earns AAdvantage miles

finalBooking.property: American Airlines 1245, Seat 14C + Thursday red-eye return
finalBooking.why: Met timing requirements, earns miles, aisle seat
finalBooking.extras: AAdvantage miles earned automatically, receipt sent to work email

outcome: He's booked 11 trips with us since. Calls us "the best travel hack I've found." 3 minutes from request to confirmed booking. No app switching, no logging in, no seat map hunting.
